channel.title: Posts on Evangeline M Reynolds
channel.description: Recent content in Posts on Evangeline M Reynolds

item.title: Layered Presentation of Graphics with +aes() in ggplot2
item.description: library(tidyverse) ## ── Attaching packages ──────── ## ✔ ggplot2 2.2.1 ✔ purrr 0.2.4 ## ✔ tibble 1.4.2 ✔ dplyr 0.7.5 ## ✔ tidyr 0.8.1 ✔ stringr 1.3.1 ## ✔ readr 1.1.1 ✔ forcats 0.3.0 ## ── Conflicts ───────────────── ## ✖ dplyr::filter() masks stats::filter() ## ✖ dplyr::lag() masks stats::lag() library(gapminder) data = gapminder %>% filter(continent == "Americas" & year == 2002) ggplot(data, aes(x = gdpPercap)) last_plot() + geom_point(aes(y = lifeExp, alpha = country == "Chile")) + scale_alpha_discrete(guide = FALSE, range = c(0,0)) last_plot() + scale_alpha_discrete(guide = FALSE, range = c(.

item.title: Winter Games and Athlete Ages
item.description: Someone asked me to share my strategy for creating the Winter Olympic Medals plot for the initiative #MakeoverMonday, which is primarily an activity of Tableau enthusiasts practicing data visualization techniques. It also serves as a forum for chatting about what works and what doesn’t work in communication data visually. Here is how I created my submission using the R statistical software and the ggplot2 package. First, we load some packages and the data

item.title: First Blogdown blogpost
item.description: This is my first post. It’s just a test of blogdown. Update: It seems to be working fine! Now I’ll knit in some R code: x = 5 x^2 ## [1] 25 Let’s check out how a graph looks too: library(ggplot2) ggplot(mtcars) + aes(mpg, disp, col = as.factor(cyl)) + geom_point() Looks good. I’m very satisfied. Hooray for blogdown!

item.title: Academic Hugo and Blogdown
item.description:
About Academic Hugo from the creator: Academic is a framework to help you create a beautiful website quickly. Perfect for personal sites, blogs, or business/project sites. Check out the latest demo of what you’ll get in less than 10 minutes. Then head on over to the Quick Start guide or take a look at the Release Notes.
About Blogdown: https://bookdown.org/yihui/blogdown/ https://alison.rbind.io/post/up-and-running-with-blogdown/ (very helpful step-by-step instructions)
